hawaiian_text: Iā lāua e noho ana, iho maila ‘o Puali‘i, he  kanaka maika‘i no Līhu‘e, i ka lawai‘a ma kai o  Honouliuli, kipa maila ia ma ka hale o Pōka‘ī. Nānā  akula ‘o Puali‘i iā Pōka‘ī a makemake akula iā ia,  ‘ōlelo akula ia: “Makemake au iā ‘oe i wahine  na‘u.” ‘Ī mai ‘o Pōka‘ī: “Pehea ‘oe e makemake ai  ia‘u? Ua hānau wau i ke keiki, a ua ‘ino‘ino ko‘u  kino.” ‘Ī aku ‘o Puali‘i: “He mea ‘ole ia mau mea, ke  makemake ‘oe ia‘u, e moe kāua.”‘Ae akula ‘o  Pōka‘ī. A ho‘i akula ‘o Pōka‘ī me kāna kāne me  Puali‘i ā ke kula o Keahumoa, noho.
llama-3.3-70B-Instruct_exl2_6.0bpw-maui_: While they were living there, Puali‘i, a good man from Līhu‘e, went fishing in the sea of Honouliuli, and visited Pōka‘ī's house. Puali‘i saw Pōka‘ī and desired her, saying: “I desire you as my woman.” Pōka‘ī replied: “Why do you desire me? I have given birth to a child, and my body is weary.” Puali‘i said: “Those things are nothing, if you desire me, we will sleep together.” Pōka‘ī agreed. And Pōka‘ī returned with her husband and Puali‘i to the plains of Keahumoa, to live.

**Paragraph 3:** 
• This paragraph introduces a new character, Pua-li‘i (Pua-li‘i: the assembly of chiefs or a chief's gathering), who is described as a kanaka maika‘i (good man) from Lī-hu‘e (sheltered calm or peaceful refuge). 
– The term kanaka maika‘i highlights Pua-li‘i's positive character traits, which may imply a sense of respectability, kindness, or fairness, all of which are highly valued in Hawaiian culture.
• Puali‘i is engaged in the activity of lawai‘a (fishing), specifically in the kai (sea) of Hono-uli-uli (calm or peaceful bay), which may symbolize a sense of tranquility or peacefulness. 
– The bay of Hono-uli-uli could be an actual location, but it may also represent a symbolic or metaphorical space, perhaps indicating a place of refuge or safety.
• Puali‘i visits the hale (house) of Pō-ka-‘ī (perhaps 'night falls upon the high chief'), where he sees and desires her, expressing his desire to make her his wahine (woman). 
– The name Pō-ka-‘ī may imply a connection to the night or the spiritual realm, and her character may represent a feminine or receptive principle.
• Pōka‘ī responds by mentioning her past experience of giving birth to a child (ke keiki, referring to Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o) and her current state of physical weariness (‘ino‘ino ko‘u kino). 
– This exchange may allude to the cultural significance of childbirth and the physical and emotional challenges associated with it, particularly during the 'Ai Kapu era, where women's roles and responsibilities were strictly defined.
• Puali‘i dismisses Pōka‘ī's concerns, stating that these factors are of no importance (hea mea ‘ole) if she desires him, and they can moe kāua (sleep together). 
– This statement may symbolize the desire for intimacy, connection, or union, which could have deeper allegorical meanings in the context of Hawaiian mythology and cultural practices.
• Pōka‘ī agrees to Puali‘i's proposal, and they return to the kula (plains) of Ke-ahumoa (the misty or foggy upland), where they will live together. 
– The name Ke-ahumoa may represent a place of transition, ambiguity, or transformation, which could be significant in the context of the story, particularly in relation to the characters' personal growth, relationships, or the broader cultural and historical context.
• The events in this paragraph may be seen as a reflection of the social and cultural norms of the time, including the 'Ai Kapu era's strict rules and regulations regarding relationships, marriage, and family. 
– The story may be using these events to comment on or critique certain aspects of Hawaiian society during this period, such as the restrictions on women's roles and the emphasis on social hierarchy and status.
raw_response:
<translation>While they were living there, Puali‘i, a good man from Līhu‘e, went fishing in the sea of Honouliuli, and visited Pōka‘ī's house. Puali‘i saw Pōka‘ī and desired her, saying: “I desire you as my woman.” Pōka‘ī replied: “Why do you desire me? I have given birth to a child, and my body is weary.” Puali‘i said: “Those things are nothing, if you desire me, we will sleep together.” Pōka‘ī agreed. And Pōka‘ī returned with her husband and Puali‘i to the plains of Keahumoa, to live.</translation>

<commentary>**Paragraph 3:** 
• This paragraph introduces a new character, Pua-li‘i (Pua-li‘i: the assembly of chiefs or a chief's gathering), who is described as a kanaka maika‘i (good man) from Lī-hu‘e (sheltered calm or peaceful refuge).

– The bay of Hono-uli-uli could be an actual location, but it may also represent a symbolic or metaphorical space, perhaps indicating a place of refuge or safety.
• Puali‘i visits the hale (house) of Pō-ka-‘ī (perhaps 'night falls upon the high chief'), where he sees and desires her, expressing his desire to make her his wahine (woman). 
– The name Pō-ka-‘ī may imply a connection to the night or the spiritual realm, and her character may represent a feminine or receptive principle.
• Pōka‘ī responds by mentioning her past experience of giving birth to a child (ke keiki, referring to Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o) and her current state of physical weariness (‘ino‘ino ko‘u kino). 
– This exchange may allude to the cultural significance of childbirth and the physical and emotional challenges associated with it, particularly during the 'Ai Kapu era, where women's roles and responsibilities were strictly defined.
• Puali‘i dismisses Pōka‘ī's concerns, stating that these factors are of no importance (hea mea ‘ole) if she desires him, and they can moe kāua (sleep together). 
– This statement may symbolize the desire for intimacy, connection, or union, which could have deeper allegorical meanings in the context of Hawaiian mythology and cultural practices.
• Pōka‘ī agrees to Puali‘i's proposal, and they return to the kula (plains) of Ke-ahumoa (the misty or foggy upland), where they will live together. 
– The name Ke-ahumoa may represent a place of transition, ambiguity, or transformation, which could be significant in the context of the story, particularly in relation to the characters' personal growth, relationships, or the broader cultural and historical context.
• The events in this paragraph may be seen as a reflection of the social and cultural norms of the time, including the 'Ai Kapu era's strict rules and regulations regarding relationships, marriage, and family. 
– The story may be using these events to comment on or critique certain aspects of Hawaiian society during this period, such as the restrictions on women's roles and the emphasis on social hierarchy and status.</commentary>
reference_translation: The two were going about their life when Puali‘i,  a good man, arrived from inland in Līhu‘e, to go  fishing on the shore of Honouliuli. He paid a visit to  the home of Pōka‘ī and looked at her and liked  her. He said, “I’d like you to be my woman.” Pōka‘ī  replied, “How could you possibly want me? I’ve  given birth to a child and my body is ruined.”  Puali‘i said, “I don’t care about that. If you like me,  let’s sleep together.” Pōka‘ī agreed and she went  with Puali‘i, now her man, to the plains of  Keahumoa to live.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 3:**• A new character is introduced, Pua-(a)li‘i  (child/descendant of a chief/chiefly line), described  as a good man, arrived from inland at Līhu‘e  (Wāhiāwā), to go fishing at Hono-uliuli (dark bay) in  ‘Ewa, somewhere in the area where Pō-ka-‘ī was  living with her baby, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o.  – In the ‘Ai Kapu era, everyone walked on land to  every destination and it was normal to call in to the  house of strangers and ask for food and water. It  was normal to receive strangers at one’s home and  provide them with food and water, and it was  considered rude to refuse generosity. This is a  custom recounted in many stories. This is likely the  reason Pua-li‘i called in at Pōka‘ī’s house and why  Pōka‘ī received Pua-li‘i in her home, where he  observed how she was living;  • Pua-li‘i falls in love with Pō-ka-‘ī and proposes a  longterm relationship. Pō-ka-‘ī expresses hesitation  due to a negative self-image, but Pua-li‘i reassures her that as long as they both like each other, the two should begin a longterm relationship and   acknowledge each other as ʻkāne’ (boyfriend,  husband, longterm lover) and ʻwahine’ (girlfriend,  wife, longterm lover). The couple relocate to Ke-ahu moa (heap of chickens) in Līhu‘e (Wāhiāwā), where  Pua-li‘i is from, to live;  • It seems the meal Pua-li‘i proposed, with the cooked  head of ulua and sweet potatoes, was a kind of ‘Ai  Kapu ritual meal perhaps solidifying/formalizing their  longterm relationship;
